message.content:
To get the directory of a symbolic link in Python, you can use the `os` and `os.path` modules. Here is an example of how to do it:

```python
import os

# Assuming 'symlink_path' is the path to your symbolic link
symlink_path = "/path/to/your/symlink"

# Get the directory of the symbolic link
symlink_dir = os.path.dirname(symlink_path)

# If you need the directory of the target of the symbolic link
target_path = os.readlink(symlink_path)
target_dir = os.path.dirname(target_path)

print("Directory of the symbolic link:", symlink_dir)
print("Directory of the target of the symbolic link:", target_dir)
```

This code snippet first retrieves the directory of the symbolic link itself using `os.path.dirname()`. If you need the directory of the file or directory to which the symbolic link points, you can use `os.readlink()` to get the path of the target and then apply `os.path.dirname()` to it.

@EOF@
[Python, os module, os.path, symbolic link, directory, readlink, dirname]
